frontMatter.title: CS-3 ː Story of the Caterpillar and the Peacock #2
frontMatter.author: Halbi Text. (CS-3) c1974. Originally typed in Devanagari by Chingaru. Researcher: Fran Woods

textInfo.textTitle: CS-3 ː Story of the Caterpillar and the Peacock #2

interlinear.free: A caterpillar and a peacock formed a mit friendship.
One day they decided between them.
The peacock is saying.
It said, "let's got eat puran root, Friend".
Then the caterpillar said.
"No, Friend, let's go eat the dʒʰuɽãɡ plant ."
So the peacock said, "Okay."
And the peacock got the caterpillar to climb on its back.
And having flown it first took it (the caterpillar) it to the dʒʰuɽãɡ garden.
And it caused it to descend.
It descended.
The caterpillar is eating (the dʒʰuɽãɡ plant).
Having eaten and eaten the caterpillar is saying.
Having said they were conversing, "You said thus 'Friend let's go eat puran root' (but) I (caterpillar) said thus, 'Friend let's go eat dʒʰuɽãɡ plant."
And the garden owner heard (them).
And he is saying.
He said, "what sort of thing is it that's singing in the dʒʰuɽãɡ garden?"
And he went.
At the time of going the peacock flew away.
It didn't get the caterpillar to climb (on its back).
It forgot.
It quickly left on its own.
Then the caterpillar said.

"You said thus 'Friend let's go eat dʒʰuɽãɡ plant' (but) I said thus, 'Friend let's go eat the puran plant."
There seems a muddle about who suggested going to eat the dʒʰuɽãɡ plant and who suggested the puran root. Initially, the caterpillar suggested the dʒʰuɽãɡ plant while the peacock suggested the puran plant. In this sentence it's reversed.
The garden owner is saying.
Having said, "what sort of thing is it that's singing so beautifully?" at that place having turned around and around and looking and looking he stepped on it (the caterpillar).
That caterpillar was near where the garden owner was standing.
It's finished.
